description: This didatic course examines the diagnostic and management issues related to the care of acutely ill adults. Students will examine the pathophysiologic as well as the psychosocial influences underlying acute illness and injury. The dynamic interplay of assessment, diagnosis, management and treatment options relevant to patients with acute illnesses and injuries will be examined in detail. An evidence-based approach to the nursing and medical management as well as pharmacologic and other therapies will be emphasized. Content will focus on patients with cardiovascular, pulmonary, infectious and nutritional issues.
name: PRINCIPLES OF ACUTE CARE I

values.comments:
This didatic course examines the diagnostic and management issues related to the
care of acutely ill adults. Students examine the pathophysiologic as well as the
psychosocial influences underlying acute illness and injury. The dynamic interplay of
assessment, diagnosis, management and treatment options relevant to patients with acute
illnesses and injuries are examined in detail. An evidence-based approach to the nursing
and medical management as well as pharmacologic and other therapies isemphasized.
Content focuses on patients with cardiovascular, pulmonary, infectious and nutritional
issues.
Overall, students found this course to be “very informative” and “an excellent
class.” Furthermore, students praised that the course was “very well organized.”
Many students praised Pawlow as “extrmely approachable” and an “excellent
instructor.” Students lauded Pawlow’s “reasonable” expectations, but they lamented the
“variability” in the quality of the guest lecturers.
Most students praised highly this course as “pertinent and interesting,” and they
“enjoyed hearing from experts.” Many students felt that the research paper is “super
labor intensive, but very rewarding in the amount of knowledge learned.”

This didactic course examines the diagnostic and management issues related to
the care of acutely ill adults. Students examine the pathophysiologic as well as the
psychosocial influences underlying acute illness and injury. The dynamic interplay of
assessment, diagnosis, management and treatment options relevant to patients with acute
illnesses and injuries is examined in detail. An evidence-based approach to the nursing
and medical management as well as pharmacologic and other therapies are emphasized.
Content focuses on patients with cardiovascular, pulmonary, infectious and nutritional
issues.
Students enjoyed the class, calling the material "pertinent" and "informative." One
student remarked that the course was "very well organized." Students considered the
exploration of the material “thorough.”
The course is co-taught by Professors Quiaoit, Doherty, and Pawlow. Students
remarked that the instructors were "approachable" and "reasonable in their expectations."
The guest speakers were described as "excellent for the most part."
Students benefited from the clear expectations and fair grading, although several
noted the difficulty of the final assignment.
